text: A wrecked Ford Mustang burns in the middle of the empty bridge. Empty. No other cars, no people in sight.. There is a gaping hole in the windshield on the driver's side. Flames consume the backseat. Smoke spills out the windows. The radio still plays, however: The Band's "I Sh be Released." One of the Mustang's front tires has blown out. Scraps of black rubber litter the accident scene. As the camera pulls in, we see HENRY LETHAM, twenty, sitt in front of the ruined car. His eyes are closed. He looks sick-- pale, skinny, disheveled-- but he has a presence, a magnetism that compels you to look at him. Finally Henry opens his eyes. After a moment he stands an walks away from the burning car, never turning around, heading for the illuminated towers of Manhattan. Somewhere nearby a BABY is HOWLING, though no one is in sight.

Tuesday The baby's HOWL continues, faintly, in the background. DR. SAM FOSTER, a psychiatrist in his early forties, wake in bed, disoriented, sunlight shining on the disheveled sheets. For several seconds Sam looks about the apartment, confus as if he's never seen the place before.

Sam parks his old, battered Volvo in front of the Chinese noodle shop. He checks his watch and curses under his bre Sam's hair is beginning to gray, but he's still built lik college tennis player. He smiles readily but there is a brooding quality about him, in his dark eyes, that sugges he has seen things most of us have not

The bells are tolling. Sam dashes through the campus gate Under his tweed blazer he wears a frayed navy-blue cable- sweater. As he rounds a corner he checks his watch, and before he looks up collides with LILA CULPEPPER, knocking her styro cup of coffee to the sidewalk With her stylish haircut and clothing, Lila looks more li young editor of a fashion magazine than a graduate studen Only the thick philosophy textbooks she carries and her r ink stained fingers give her away. She shoves him.
Watch where you're going, old man.
Jesus, kids these days... He kisses her on the lips.

I don't have time to stand here flirting with you. I've got to give a test to Grunbaum's undergrads. Sam stoops to pick up the empty cup, stands straight, crumples the cup, tosses it into a nearby garbage can.
Thank God none of the TAs looked like you when I was a student. I would've flunked every test.
(unimpressed) Oh, that's sweet. Can I tell you something? She sidles up next to him and fixes the collar of his jac
What?
You owe me a cup of coffee.
Sam hurries inside the sleek, angular, glass-and-steel building.
Sam gets out of the elevator and waves to a RECEPTIONIST sitting behind a desk. A sign on the wall behind her read

head_text.subj: COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY COUNSELING AND PSYCHOLOGICAL SERVICES

text: Hey, Toni.
Hey, Sam. Henry Letham's waiting in Beth's office.
Thanks. He walks down the hallway and opens the last door on the left.

Henry, wearing paint-spattered army pants and a black lon sleeve tee-shirt, stands at the window of the bookshelf-l office, looking out at the sky. He stares at Sam when Sam enters the room. Sam smiles and nods.
Henry?
Where's Dr. Levy?

Dr. Levy had an appendectomy, she'll be gone a few weeks. I'm Dr. Foster, I'm covering for her. Sam offers his hand and Henry examines it for a moment be shaking. Sam goes behind the desk to sit and gestures for Henry to sit inn one of the facing chairs. Sam pulls a manila folder from his suitcase. Henry sits o the edge of a facing chair. He looks ready to bolt at any second. Henry holds a piece of string which he coils tightly aro his index finger, then uncoils, then coils again.
So you're the substitute shrink? Sam smiles.
I guess you could call me that. Does it make you uncomfortable that I'm filling in for Dr. Levy? Henry thinks about it, coiling the string tightly.
Is she your girlfriend?
No. We were classmates, actually. So listen, I read your file--
Oh, really? May I read your file?
Fair enough. How about you ask me a question for every question I ask you?
How about we don't play stupid games. Sam smiles and leans back in his chair. Far from being deterred by Henry's attitude, he's intrigued. He likes challenges.
Okay. Tell me why you're here.
You read the file. You ought to know.
You torched your car. Why?
I don't know.
What do you mean, you don't know?
I don't remember.
Were you drinking?
I opened my eyes and I was sitting in the car and it was on fire. Henry is quiet for a moment, remembering.
Do you often set fires?
No. I'm not a pyromaniac or anything. It's not like I burned flies when I was a kid. (beat) Maybe a couple times I did. Is that bad?
For the flies it is.
I remember them trying to crawl when they were on fire. Henry is silent for a moment. He coils the string so tigh around his finger that the tip of his finger turns bright red.
Maybe Hell is the place where all the bad things you've done come back to get you. Another pause. Sam points at Henry's finger.
You're cutting off the circulation.
I never meant to hurt anyone.
You were a kid. Kids are cruel.
I'm not talking about the flies.
What are you talking about? Abruptly, Henry stands, knocking over his chair in the process. He bends down to pick it up.
Sorry. I better go.
Are you sure? I feel like we're just getting started.
No, no, I better-- Henry looks out the window.
We'll have hail this afternoon. Sam watches him leave and then stares out the window. The is bright blue.

The sky is still blue on this beautiful autumn afternoon. and Lila, on rollerblades, slowly roll down the promenade overlooking the Hudson River. Lila holds Sam's hand, steadying him. Lila is obviously skilled; Sam is obviously a beginner. H wears a helmet, kneepads, and elbow pads over his long-sl tee-shirt.
Don't lean forward too much.
Okay.
Try to relax. You're too tense. Try to get the rhythm. You want it to feel natural.

I have wheels strapped to my feet There's nothing natural about it. Two kids on rollerblades whiz by the couple. Sam, trying get out of the way, nearly falls.  One of the kids begins skating backwards. He nudges his friend and imitates Sam's spastic motions. Both of them l and zoom away.
Ha ha, you little bastards.
We don't have to do this, you know. It's supposed to be fun.
I'm having fun. He lets go of Lila's hand and tries to skate in the manne Eric Heiden, pumping his legs with one hand behind his ba going faster and faster.
Sam... Sam, now out of control, begins speeding downhill.

How do I stop? HOW DO I STOP? Ahead of him, the path forks left and right. He won't be to make the turn at this speed. At the last second, Sam grabs onto a lamppost. He spins around the post and flops into a bush.

(catching up) Sam? Sam? Sam lies on the ground, catching his breath. He's covered with leaves and dirt. LILA (CONTвЂ™D) You okay? Lila crouches beside him and begins checking him for inju with the practiced skill of a nurse.
I'm fine, I'm fine.
That was impressive. She lies down next to him.
Maybe I'm not ready for this. I'm not so coordinated.

That's okay. You're a sexy klutz. They kiss. Lila pulls herself closer, her hands on Sam's wrists. Abruptly, Sam pulls his long sleeves down farther if to hide something on his wrists. Lila releases him. For a moment both of them are quiet.
You don't have to do that. You don't have to hide from me. Sam doesn't look at her.
I'm not hiding.
Sam. Sam raises his head.
Don't hide. She kisses him. In the middle of the kiss a loud CRACK startles both of them.
What was that? For a few seconds nothing happens. And then another CRACK and then another, coming rapid fire now, grape-size chunk ice falling from the sky and shattering on the paved walkways.
Hail.

We see the road through the driver's eyes. We're somewher Brooklyn, driving fast through a string of green lights. Everything is very, very quiet. We turn to the right. A GREEN-EYED WOMAN (20) sits in th passenger seat. She says something, but we can't hear a w She smiles.

Henry opens his eyes. He sits in a car that shudders and rattles its way through the underground. On his lap is a on the artist Tristan RГ©veur. He pulls a cigarette from a pack and lights it. Next to Henry sleeps a long-haired TEENAGE BOY wearing a Walkman: from the headphones we hear "I Shall be Released Various subway riders glare at Henry and wave away the sm obviously annoyed that he's polluting their airspace. A YOUNG WOMAN who wears her blonde hair in dreadlocks sit across the car, watching Henry.

You go to Columbia, right? We were both in Psych 221. Professor Matthewson? (pointing at his book) You did your oral presentation on psychosis and Tristan RГ©veur right? Henry stares at her as if she's speaking an alien languag BUSINESSMAN standing between them, holding onto the metal pole, wearing a gray suit and carrying an attache case, shakes his head at Henry.
No smoking on the train.
What?
(pointing) Look at the sign, fella. No smoking on the train. Henry looks at the sign.
Capeesh? Put it out.
Capeesh? Are you in the Mafia? The businessman leans closer, until his face is inches fr Henry's.

Put out the fucking cigarette. Henry slowly rolls his shirtsleeve back from his forearm. skin is mottled with fresh burns. He draws on his cigarette until its point is red-hot, the stabs it out on the skin of his wrist. He does not flinch The businessman reels backward. The dreadlocked Columbia student's mouth drops open. The people sitting next to He stand and move away. Henry offers the cigarette butt to the businessman, who w his hand at it and moves away, muttering:
You ought to be locked up.
I am. When the train pulls into the next station, the businessm and the Columbia caucastafarian hastily depart.

Bookshelves overflowing with books dominate the space. Th one luxurious feature is a working fireplace where a well built little fire now burns. Lila's curled up in bed, highlighting lines in Dante's Purgatorio. Sam, lying beside her, speaks on the PHONE.

Hey, Beth, this is Sam. Hope you're feeling better. I met with your patient Henry Letham today, thought maybe we could compare notes. Anyway, give me a call.  11. He hangs up and stares into the fire, his hands folded ov his chest.
(to Lila) You don't think it's a little odd, predicting a hailstorm like that?
(not really paying attention) So he watches the Weather Channel.
I looked in the newspaper. There was nothing about any hail today.
Maybe he's a shaman and he did a little hail dance.
Okay, forget it.
(finally looking up) How's Beth Levy?
I don't know. She hasn't returned any of my calls.
Hm.
What does "hm" mean?
She always kind of liked you didn't she? Sam jabs Lila in the ribs with his finger.
What are you, jealous? Beth's one of my oldest friends.
She's your oldest friend, that's supposed to make me unjealous?  12.
Unjealous?
She's in love. It's obvious to everyone but you. And every day you wear that sweater she made you-- She points at the blue sweater, lying folded on top of th dresser.
--and all I can think is, Damn, I can't even knit.
She saved my life, sweetheart.
I know.
You're the only one for me, all right? I knew I would find you. And I did.
(kissing him on the lips) It took you long enough.
Wednesday Sam sits behind Beth's desk and Henry sits facing him.
Have you considered a career in meteorology? Henry says nothing, only stares at the chewed-down stubs his fingernails.
The weatherman said something about the hail?
I can't listen to the weatherman anymore. I don't understand a word he says.  13.
You don't understand the weatherman?
Do you?
Sure. He says rain, I bring an umbrella. Henry stares at Sam for a moment, trying to gauge the psychiatrist. He seems to come to a decision.
I don't know what's real anymore.
Go on. (off Henry's non-response) Give me a chance, Henry. I'm good at what I do.
The voices never stop.
Voices?
In my head. They never stop.
Why were you so reluctant to tell me that?
I don't want to fit into your grid. I don't want you saying, "Okay, paranoid schizophrenic. Two hundred milligrams of Risperdol should do the trick."
You don't want me making assumptions about you, right? Henry nods.
But aren't you making assumptions about me? You think I want to fit you into a grid? (MORE )

SAM(cont 'd) I don't make grids. I want to know the particulars about Henry Letham. You hear voices. All right, that's important information. What are the voices saying? Henry shakes his head and looks out the window.
I think it might be helpful if you start writing it down.
Writing what down?
What the voices are saying. write down the exact words when you hear them. Okay? Henry? Henry hasn't been listening.
What?
Write down what the voices are saying. Henry grabs a pen and a pad of paper from the desk and be writing.
They're talking to you now? Henry continues writing furiously. When he finishes he st at his own jagged cursive
Can I see? Henry hands the pad over. Sam studies it, straining to re the handwriting.
(reading) "Write down what the voices are saying... They're talking to you now?" (looking at Henry) That wasn't a hallucination, that was me talking.  15.
You come inside my head, Doctor, and show me how to tell the difference.
(continuing to read) "Stay, Henry, stay. Stay. Stay. Stay." (looking at Henry) You're hearing this voice now? Henry nods, rubbing his palm over his scarred forearm.
Do you recognize the voice?
Yes.
Who is it?
I don't know.
You just said you did.
It's a woman. I know her, but I don't know who she is.
I don't understand. Henry says nothing, only scratches his forearm. Sam notic the fresh burn on Henry's arm. He stands, goes around the desk, gently takes Henry's arm and inspects it.
What's this from?
I burned myself. Sam looks closer. He notices the old burn scars that constellate Henry's forearms.
(more firmly) What are these scars from?  16. Absently, Henry looks at his forearms.
Cigarettes, I guess.
Why do you have cigarette scars on your forearms?
Because I keep burning myself. Sam nods and studies Henry for a moment. He releases Henr arm and sits on the edge of the desk
Why do you want to hurt yourself?
I guess it's practice.
Practice for what?
For Hell. Sam takes a deep breath and exhales.
You think you're going to Hell? Henry nods.
Why?
Because of what I did.
What did you do? Henry shakes his head, stares out the window.
Whatever it is, we--
I know you're trying to help me, Doctor. And thank you. But it's too late.  17.
Why is it too late? Henry stands and grabs his bookbag off the floor.
Saturday at midnight I'm going to kill myself. He rubs his arms and smiles.
I need to get ready. He walks out, leaving a stunned Sam alone in the room.

Sam walks down the corridor of the Mental Health Ward. He knocks on an office door marked: Mobile Crisis Unit. No answer. As he's about to knock again he hears a commotion the end of the hallway. Two strapping PARAMEDICS are wrestling a fiercely agitate heavy-set woman, DAISY, toward one of the rooms. She appe to be homeless, wearing layer upon layer of filthy clothi her hair matted, her skin dirty and bruised. Standing beside the paramedics, DOCTOR SCHLEGEL, a gaunt with a sparse goatee, tries to calm the woman.
Come on, Daisy. We've got your television turned on and everything. Take it easy.

Nobody's calling you a Nazi, Daisy. Come on, now. Sam hurries down the corridor toward the disturbance. Dai falls to the floor and the paramedics, unable to force he into the room, try to hold her still as she thrashes in t arms. Dr. Schlegel has prepared a hypodermic and now crouches waiting for an opportunity to stick Daisy.  18.
I know it, Daisy, I know it.
(beginning to sob) You can't treat me this way. I am not a Nazi! I don't deserve this.

Believe it or not, sweetheart, it's for your own good. The paramedics hold her tight and Schlegel sticks the nee in Daisy's arm. DR. SCHLEGEL (CONTвЂ™D) If you'd remember to take your pills, we wouldn't have to go through this every month.
I'm not a Nazi. I'm lovable.
You are.
(already beginning to fade) I'm lovable. The paramedics hoist Daisy to her feet and lead her peacefully into the bedroom. Dr. Schlegel sees Sam for the first time and smiles, a li embarrassed.
Hey, Sam. The glamorous world of psychiatry, huh? They shake hands and Schlegel leads Sam back toward the Mobile Crisis Unit office.
So what brings you to Club Meds?
I wanted to check the protocol on involuntary committal. (MORE)
SAM(cont'd) I've got a student threatening to kill himself.

Jesus, tell him to take a number Well, the rules are pretty straightforward. If he says he's gonna hurt himself or someone else, we can take him in. But we can only hold him here for forty-eight hours.
Forty-eight hours? What are we going to do in forty-eight hours? They stop outside the MCU office.
Hold his hand, feed him some pills. (beat) If we catch him in the actual attempt, that's different. He's broken the law. But just based on a threat? Without a court order, we can't keep him for long.
He wants to do it Saturday at midnight. If we take him in now he'll be out by then.
What, he's got an appointment to off himself?
That's what he told me. Saturday, midnight.

So maybe we should pick him up Friday, hold him through the weekend. (shaking his head) AS you just saw, it's not a real fun process. If there's any way to avoid it, avoid it. What do you have him on?
He won't take any pills. (beat) (MORE)
SAM(cont'd) He wants to die, Jeff. I've got three days to convince him not to.

Sam is walking home when he stops to watch PIANO MOVERS a work. Using ropes and pulleys, they hoist a Bechstein bab grand toward the open windows of a fourth-floor apartment PIANO MOVER 1 acts as the foreman, issuing commands.
Easy, easy. A small BOY, accompanied by his MOTHER, runs down the str holding a red balloon. He trips and falls and the balloon begins to float away.

(yelling at escaping balloon) Wait! wait! The piano movers hear the boy's cries and see the balloon Piano Mover 1 makes a valiant effort to capture the escap balloon; he runs after it and leaps... but he can't quite reach it. Everyone watches the red balloon drift skyward.
Sorry, kid. It's gone to balloon heaven. Sam smiles and enters his building, where the DOORMAN gre him.
Lila meets Sam at the door and kisses him on the lips.
I didn't think you were going to make it. I need you to make a fire. You're the only Eagle Scout I've ever dated. She leads him into the bedroom.  21.
I never made Eagle Scout. The Troop Master caught me drinking Mad Dog 20/20 in my tent with Lydia Eumanian.
Lydia Eumanian?
The horniest thirteen-year-old in Northern New Jersey. Lila curls up at the foot of her bed and watches as Sam g a bundle of twigs from beside the fireplace and starts la down the kindling.
Only because I never lived in Northern New Jersey. Sam begins stacking the logs.
Are you okay, baby? You look a little tense.
That student. Henry. He told me he was going to kill himself Saturday night.
Kids at Columbia are always talking about killing themselves. It's hip. It's like wearing black.
I don't think it's a front for this one. Saturday at midnight, he says. Just like that. Like it's a date he's made. Sam rolls an old newspaper and inserts it beneath the sta logs.
Why Saturday? Sam strikes a match and lights the fire.
Why does he want to do it on Saturday? What's so special about midnight Saturday? Sam watches the kindling catch.
He left before I could ask. Confident that the fire is in good shape, Sam walks over the bedside table, picks up the phone and dials a number. waits for a moment and then shakes his head.
(on phone) Beth, it's Sam again. Where are you? You all right? Uh, okay, give me a call when you get this. He hangs up and sits on the edge of the bed.
I'm starting to get a little worried about her.
I'm starting to get a little worried about you, baby. It's a hell of a job, listening to these crazy boys and girls all day.
At least I get you all night. Lila grabs Sam by the collar and pulls him over to her. T kiss.
Don't go crazy on me.
Thursday Sam sits behind the desk and Henry sits facing him. Sam h a typed contract.
I want to propose a deal. I've written up a contract. (MORE)

SAM(cont 'd) It says you won't do anything to hurt yourself without contacting me first. And here's my card. It has my home phone and cell phone, so you can call me whenever you want. Henry leans forward and takes the contract and business c from Sam. He reads the contract quickly, signs his name, hands it back to Sam. He pockets the card.
Saturday at midnight I die. Consider yourself contacted. Sam, bewildered, looks at the contract for a moment and t sets it aside.
Why Saturday?
It's my twenty-first birthday.
I think the tradition is to go out and get drunk, not blow your brains out.

Have you heard of Tristan RГ©veur? He was one of the Dada artists. When he was eighteen he told everyone he would live three more years and then go to New York and kill himself. And that's exactly what he did. He came to New York for his twenty-first birthday, saw the sights, and shot himself in the head. Both of them are silent for a while.
What about your parents? Have you considered what this might do to them?
They don't care.
How do you know that?  24.
It's pretty obvious.
Do they live around here?
No. They're over in Mahlus Gardens.
Mahlus Gardens? Where's that?
It's a cemetery in New Jersey. I thought you read my file.
(startled) I did. It didn't mention anything about that.
It's a little out of date, then. Henry stands, walks over to the office window and looks o across the campus.
Any other family? Henry shakes his head.
Friends? (off Henry's silence) Who are you closest to?
What do you mean, closest to?
If you got into trouble and you needed someone, who would you go to?
I am in trouble. Henry does not say this in a self-pitying way. He is simp stating a fact.
Yes, I think you are.  25.
Then you've got your answer. Sam does not understand.
I came to you, Doctor. I guess that means I'm closest to you.
To me? We met two days ago. Henry inspects his fingernails.
There was a girl.
(perking up) A girlfriend?

I barely even talked to her. She was my waitress at this diner I used to go to. On Canal Street. (beat) She'd keep filling my coffee cup. She'd say, "Is everything okay?" I mean, I know waitresses are always asking that, but... this is stupid.
No, it's not stupid. This waitress did you ever get her name?
Athena.
Athena? Really? (beat) All right, that's a start.
No, it's not. She was in my life for a few minutes and now she's gone.
She's not gone. She's somewhere else.  26.
There is no somewhere else. If you're not in my life, you don't exist.
(smiling) You think I disappear when you're not watching?
I'm always watching.

We're back in the DRIVER'S POV again, speeding along the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway. The Brooklyn Bridge looms in distance, Gothic arches majestically lit We look at the green-eyed woman, but she's speaking to someone in the backseat. Her mouth moves but everything i silent. We turn to the road again. The bridge is waiting for us.

Henry enters the Zoo beneath the Delacorte Clock, the bro animals playing their instruments, marking the hour. Henry watches a lone silverback GORILLA who sits on a lar rock, staring back at Henry. Henry sits on a park bench, watching an OLD MAN throw bre crumbs to a horde of squawking pigeons. Henry sits in the last row of the bleachers overlooking t seal pool. The front rows are filled with screaming CHILD On an island in the middle of the pool, TRAINERS toss fis the SEALS as rewards for various tricks: clapping their flippers, jumping through hoops, kissing each other balancing balls on their noses.

We see a blurred Henry through the window of a polar bear tank. The BEAR is swimming laps, never pausing.  27. It's an oddly graceful animal, bulky but elegant, flippin each end of the pool to kick off the wall (one wall being window that Henry stands behind).
Henry seems mesmerized by the bear's endless swim. A well dressed ENGLISHMAN and ENGLISHWOMAN approach and watch th bear perform its laps.
(to Henry) You suppose he's bored?
I think he's trying to forget where he is. The Englishman nods and they all watch the bear in silenc for a moment.
The polar bear glides soundlessly through the water, igno the blurred faces beyond the glass.
Somewhere nearby a BABY is howling. Henry looks around bu there is no baby in sight.
And is it working? Henry looks at the Englishman.
It's hard to forget where you are, isn't it?
You tell me. Both the man and his wife smile at Henry and walk away. H watches them go. The unseen baby continues to howl.  28.
Lila sits cross-legged in the grass lawn that fronts the Philosophy building, highlighting lines in a textbook. A feet away, Rodin's bronze Le Penseur sits in permanent contemplation.
So what's he thinking? Lila looks up from her book and sees Sam staring at the statue. She smiles and studies the Thinker for a moment.
I think therefore I am?
It's not thinking anything. It's a statue.
You're kind of literal minded, you know that? She grins and tosses aside her book.

You grade two hundred papers in a week, see how literal minded you get. (beat) You met with that student today? The suicidal one? Sam squats down beside Lila and picks at the grass. He re his BRIEFCASE on the ground beside him.
He came in, yeah.
And? Why does he want to die? Sam stares at Lila for a while and she looks away, fluste
I'm sorry, is that a stupid question? Sam shakes his head. He takes Lila's hand.  29.
No. It's the question. I just don't have an answer yet.
And you... did you... She's obviously uncomfortable, not sure how to proceed. He kisses Lila sees Sam turns Sam walks
I need to find something he wants to live for.
How are you going to do that?

He'll tell me. That's why he keeps coming to see me. (checking his watch) I've got a meeting to get to. See you at home. her on the lips, stands, and begins walking away. that he's left his briefcase lying on the ground.
Henry! and stares at her. Lila points at the briefcase.
Forgetting something? back to her, staring at her the whole time.
What's the matter?
What did you just call me?
(confused) What?
You just called me Henry.
Baby, I think I know your name by now.  30.
But you called me Henry. Lila holds up her hands.
Hey, don't shoot.
No, it's just--
I know who you are, Sam. I promise.
Okay. Okay. He grabs his briefcase, kisses her again, and walks away. watches him go.
Friday Henry sits on the sidewalk outside the cafe, playing cat' cradle with a string. He's good, creating intricate patte and undoing them. Sam walks up to him.
Hey. You're early.
I skipped glee club today.
Oh. (beat) That's a joke, right?
Yes, sir. Sam leads Henry inside.

A small, dark cafe where STUDENTS and PROFESSORS drink co and eat homemade pastries. Bad art lines the walls.  31. Henry and Sam find seats in a corner of the room, far awa from everyone else. The song playing on the radio ends; the new song is "I Sh be Released." Henry sits up straight when he hears the song. He stares the nearest stereo speaker as if trying to figure somethi out.
I can't escape this song. (looking at Sam) Why did you want to meet here?
The Hungarian Cafe? Sentimental favorite. When I was an undergrad I worked here. (pointing) I lost my virginity under that table.
(shocked) You what?

I used to lock up every night. So one time I brought my girlfriend here and we had a bottle of wine, and, you know, one thing led to another. It wasn't very comfortable. Henry laughs and shakes his head.
I never had a shrink tell me something like that.
(looking up at the artworks) They still have the same bad art on the walls.
(looking at the art) Tristan RГ©veur used to say that bad art is more tragically beautiful than good art, because bad art documents human failure.  32.

I don't know about this Tristan RГ©veur guy. I think you ought to choose your role models a little more carefully. (beat; very sober now) You do understand that I'm required by law to report anyone who physically threatens himself or others? Henry laughs.
What's funny?
You take all this so seriously.
Should I not take it seriously? Is that what you're telling me? Is this a joke?
I'm not talking about Saturday. I am going to die on Saturday. I just mean your role. The psychiatrist. You play it well. Sam considers this for a moment.
Why do you think I'm playing a role? Henry smiles but does not answer.
Are you playing a role? The Suicidal Romantic? why'd you choose that role? Why do you want to die? The smile disappears from Henry's face. He rubs his palm the burns on his forearm.
I don't want to keep hurting people.
Who did you hurt?  33.
I don't know. Henry is becoming more and more distraught. He stares at floor, picks at his fingernails. But Sam won't let it res he knows he's on to something important.
Have you done something, Henry? You've hurt someone?
I don't know. Maybe.
You do know. What have you done? Henry, still staring at the floor, begins to shake his he violently.
Is that why you're thinking about suicide? Is that it? You need to punish yourself? What happened?
I don't remember.

You don't want to remember. But you have to. You can't escape from the truth. Whatever it is you've done, you have to face it. Suddenly Henry stops shaking his head and looks straight Sam, a strange smile on his face.
If I can't escape from the truth we're all in serious trouble, Dr. Foster.

Sam and DR. LEON PATTERSON, a middle-aged blind man weari dark glasses, sit on folding chairs, facing each other ov fold-away chess table. A small radio on the grass plays Billy Holiday. Sam moves queen.  34.
Queen to g4.
Billy Holiday. I remember her singing at the Five Spot, years ago.
I wish I could have heard her
Yes. Well, I wish I could have seen her.

Here, I want to show you something. Give me your hand. Sam pulls a small, pale-blue Tiffany's box from his blaze pocket, opens it, pulls out a diamond ring and hands it t Leon. Leon rotates the ring between his fingers and rubs the st

Henry Letham.  35.

He noticed the heat or the light and his unconscious figured out a fire had started.

(to Henry) What's the matter?
(to Leon, in a dazed whisper ) What are you doing here? Leon is confused, unsure whether he's being spoken to or He withdraws his extended hand.

Henry- -

Listen--
You think I wouldn't recognize my own father?

Henry, think about it for a minute. Dr. Patterson is alive and well. Henry doesn't say anything for a while. He rubs his scarr forearms in silence. Finally, gesturing at the campus abo them, the buildings and trees and students:
Everything you believe is a lie.

We can't wait any longer.

Jesus. The room is small and almost empty: there is a bare mattr in one corner and a chair by the window. A phone and answering machine are on the chair. Trouble. Dr. Schlegel hands a small box to Sam.

Stay Henry stay stay stay Henry stay stay stay Henry stay stay stay Henry stay stay stay Henry stay stay stay Henry stay stay stay Henry stay.

Then I'll find him.

We're on the ramp leading up to the Brooklyn Bridge. The Gothic towers, massive and imposing, rise above us. It's late, traffic is light, and we're moving fast

The roof of the cathedral is so high, and the lighting so poor, that it's impossible to see the ceiling. From somewhere inside the building a BABY'S howl echoes. Sam sits at the kitchen table. The documents, from Henry' folder are spread out before him: transcripts, applicatio materials, etc.  43. (examining a memo) He refused to take the mandatory swim test. Maybe he's afraid of water.
(chewing) Mm.
Citations for Studio Art. Apparently he's an accomplished painter.
Did you ever hear from Beth Levy?
No. Listen to this: "Of all the students I have encountered at Columbia, Henry Letham has the most fertile imagination. If he maintains his concentration he will create new worlds with his art."
Clearly that professor wants to fuck Henry Letham. Sam, still paging through the documents, laughs.

What do you mean?

Maybe you're right. Maybe I ama cynic. But it seems to me that he's using you. (beat) You want your fortune cookie?

And not a moment too soon, that's all I can say. (noticing Sam's expression) What's the matter, baby? Sam?
Sam stands outside an apartment door, holding the Henry Letham folder. He rings the doorbell. No answer. He rings again. He bangs on the door. No answer.
(yelling) Beth? Finally the door opens, still chained.  45.

(quieter) Beth? It's Sam. Are you okay? DR. BETH LEVY unchains the door and walks back into the apartment. Frizz-haired and overweight, Beth looks bad. S obviously hasn't showered in days, or changed her clothes
Sam follows her inside, closing the door behind him. The light in the apartment is from the streetlights. Beth sits on the floor, her back against a sofa.
How you feeling? I'm sorry, I should have come earlier Beth is not paying any attention to him. Sam sits down a feet away from her.
Beth? (forcing a laugh) They've got you doped up on some serious painkillers, huh? what are you on, Vicodin? Percoset?
There was no surgery.
What do you mean? The appendectomy- - they decided not to operate?
I made it up.
You... why?
Do you want to play? Can we play a kissing game? She begins crawling toward him on her hands and knees.
I always wanted to kiss you. Let's play a kissing game. Okay?  46. Sam holds up his hands.
Beth... She stops abruptly and sinks back on her haunches.
No, I'm too old for you. I'm too fat. You like them young and skinny, don't you? Like that little slut you live with.
Stop. Beth's face seems on the verge of collapse.
Don't hate me, Sam. Please don't hate me.
How could I hate you?
Not that it matters. Not that any of it matters.
This has something to do with Henry Letham. Beth laughs very hard. It is not a pleasant sound.

Oh, yes, yes, it does! Hurrah, you win! It does have something to do with Henry Letham. You win the grand prize. Very good, very good, ten points. Thank you for playing, Henry. Sam cocks his head and looks at her more closely.
It's Sam.

BETH(cont 'd) I remember cleaning your bathroom floor, on my hands and knees between the tiles, behind the sink everywhere. Sam is speechless for a moment.
That was twenty years ago. What does that have to do with Henry?
Everything has to do with Henry.
You know he's planning to kill himself this weekend?
No more Mondays, anyway. That's the good news. I never liked Mondays. We played make-believe. Didn't we? We played make-believe for so many years. Except it wasn't us playing.
Do you know where I can find him? Beth?
Ask his mother.
His mother? His mother's dead.
Ask her anyway.
Sam has managed to get Beth into bed. She sleeps now whil Sam sits at the foot of the bed, looking through papers f Henry's folder. He dials a number on his CELL PHONE.
Hello? Yes,. I'm sorry to bother you at this hour. My name is Dr Sam Foster, I'm a psychiatrist at Columbia University. Yes. I'm calling about a student named Henry Letham.  48. Sam listens.
He's your son? He... I'm sorry, this is very strange. He told me you had died... Hello? Hello? Sam stares at the cell phone. He dials the number again a listens. Nobody answers.
You have no idea what's going on do you? Sam turns and sees Beth sitting up in bed, watching him. is calmer now, but her eyes are still bloodshot and wild.
He lied to me.
Trust me, Sam-- the truth is worse than the lie.
We watch the battered old Volvo glide over the Hudson beneath the lighted suspension cables.

Sam gets out of the car and walks to the doorstep. The ho is dark. Sam rings the doorbell. No answer. He rings agai

I thought you'd never come visit. She stands and approaches Sam. She has a limp. She's a ki looking woman, but weary, with dark circles below her blu eyes and wisps of gray hair straying out from under the kerchief.
I would have called earlier except... to be honest, I didn't even know you were alive.
I guess it's easy to forget me, all alone out here in the country.
Your son's not well.. That's what I'm here about. I'm trying to find him. He's... he's threatened suicide. Mrs. Letham laughs but the laugh turns into a cough. limps to the front door.
I know why you came. Not because of me. You came to see Olive, didn't you? Sam frowns.
Olive?
I know you did. She She opens the door, flicks on a light and leads him insid In the light we can see that Mrs. Letham has a wine-stain birthmark on her left cheek.  50.

The house is immaculate. The windows are spotless; the chandelier by the staircase glitters; the hardwood floor polished and gleaming. But there is no furniture to be seen anywhere. The dog is massive, at least 160 pounds slobber-jawed, its black eyes tiny in its huge head.
(under his breath) Jesus.
Here she is. She's been lonely. Me and Olive keep each other company. It feels like we've been alone in this house for a thousand years.
Hey, Olive. How you doing, girl? The mastiff stares at him impassively.
She doesn't remember you anymore, you've been away so long. (beat) Let me fix you something to eat. I have some leftovers in the fridge.

No thank you, I ate. Do you know how to contact your son? Any friends or relatives he might have gone to see? But Mrs. Letham limps into the kitchen anyway and Sam is forced to follow her. Olive pads in after them.
The kitchen shines like the rest of the house. Someone ha spent hours scrubbing every surface until it gleams. Mrs. Letham opens the refrigerator and looks through it.  51. The refrigerator is empty.
Most days I don't say a single word. I'm silent so long sometimes I forget how to speak. It's so quiet here.
Mrs. Letham, we have an emergency. Henry's in danger. Suddenly, Mrs. Letham seems close to tears. She closes th refrigerator and looks at Sam.
Do you hate me? You must hate me. Is that why you did it? Because you hate me?
I don't hate you at all. Your son needs help. That's why I'm here. Mrs. Letham smiles and takes Sam's hand.
I knew you'd come back, eventually. It was so quiet without you, so lonely. But now you've come back and you're never going to leave. Sam is quiet for a moment, searching Mrs. Letham's smilin face.
Who do you think I am, Mrs. Letham?
Don't play these games anymore. Not anymore.
Who am I?
You think I don't know you, Henry? You think I don't recognize my only son? Mrs. Letham wraps her arms around Sam and squeezes him to her.  52.
Oh Lord, I missed you. I missed you so much. I could never stay angry at you. I know you didn't mean to hurt me. Sam nods. He speaks very quietly, very carefully. They ar still locked in an embrace.
Mom?
Yes, baby?
How did I hurt you?
It doesn't matter anymore. Let's not talk about it, please.
Where do I go on the weekends?
You go the city. You've been going to the city since you were old enough to take the train.
And where do I go in the city? Abruptly, Mrs. Letham goes cool. She breaks off the hug.
You used to go to your classes before you met Athena.
Athena?
(increasingly angry) Now you might not even graduate, your grades are so bad.
Do you remember where Athena lives?  53.
Athena this, Athena that, always Athena, beautiful Athena. I'm sick of Athena! I'm sick of her!

Yes. Sheriff Kennelly pages through a notebook.

That's right.

I've got to head back to the city as soon as possible. Listen, 9625 Rickover Street: I was there. Henry's mother was there. The sheriff stares at Sam. Finally he nods and stuffs his notebook into his jacket pocket.

Sheriff?

Maureen Letham. Did she have a birthmark right here? Sam points to his left cheek. The sheriff squints at Sam.

What's going on, Sam? Sam sits on the edge of the bed, considering the question

The screen goes black. And then bright white. The white gradually resolves and we see that we're staring into the glare of a small flashlight. The flashlight disappears and Sam's face replaces it, Sam face looming large, staring directly into the camera.

Olive's not dead. She is very much not dead.

(with mock surprise) Doctor Foster!

Yes.

Do you?
Nothing. Sam looks up at the floor indicator lights. Henry looks u well. 3...2...1.
